Posts.Content: Hi there @Shielscannylass, Honey to soothe and bicarbonate of soda have worked for me. If I put a dab of bicarbonate of soda on an ulcer before I go to bed it's 90% better in the morning. I hope you find something that works for you x
Posts.Title: Pesky mouth ulcers driving me crazy

Posts.Content: Hi there, Sorry to hear you're going to be having Chemotherapy : ( The only advice I can give is to not drive after the therapy. The first one I had made me feel really 'high' and I think I would have crashed the car - I didn't drive for about 4 days after. I still don't drive to/from Chemo because you feel a bit dazed from all the medication. I'm in a similar situation to you, don't have help to hand so I get the fridge filled and make sure I'm stocked up on medication and that's about it...the SE's are best treated before they kick in, at least that's what I did with the first sitting, then just take it from there. Make sure you can stay in if you need to for a day or two. Try not to worry (I know...ha, ha) but once you're in you'll find ways to cope and then it's just a case of ticking off the days 'till this 'poop' (as Leolady says) is over... All the best and good luck Restory
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: To all of you especially Sunflower, Mazza and  Isreal  you’ve brought me to tears, thanks for sharing xxx
Posts.Title: Restless and feeling guilty about it

Posts.Content: I found this article in the Economist, it's a bit old but I thought it was interesting and was wondering if anyone has tried cutting back on food intake the days before/during and after chemio sessions and if it help with the side effects? Great title too...starving the beast! : ) www.economist.com/.../starving-the-beast
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and fasting

Posts.Content: Ditto everything...non smoker, breastfed, active etc But if theres one thing that springs to mind it's that cancer is very democratic, no one excluded! : )
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and fasting

Posts.Content: DohaYogi: thanks for sharing your experience, I'm glad you're feeling great. I'm going to look into it! summerholiday: '.....positive and in fighting mode' wow girl, that's my kinda talk! Congratulations on finishing the Chemo! I just wish I'd found out about fasting at the beginning of my therapy, I've finished my 4 Adriblastina and am now at n.2 of 12 Paclitaxel and Herceptin but I suppose it's never too late to start...(sorry, but I haven't got a clue about the name shortcuts - if anyone can tell me what they are for the above I will be forever grateful!) : )
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and fasting

Posts.Content: Reading your post I really feel for you, not just because of the insensitivity of the people who surround us (who I think are just scared witless or just have no experience of cancer so don't have a clue, so really aren't to blame in most cases) but because I imagine what it's like (and squirm at the thought - that or the bat)  - I would have struggled with the looks and comments sooo much. I dislike attention, I enjoy it only when I'm making people happy, like most people I suppose. Everything we concentrate on intensifies, so if I concentrate on the cancer in some way it grows, if the people around me identify me as 'ill' I can't get away from being ill and leave space to remember that there's another part of me that's completely healthy. If people concentrate on my illness, I'm never going to get a day off and that day that I wake up and feel at peace with the world someone is going to (unknowingly, albeit meant kindly) rain on my parade by bringing the subject up. As I've said before, I have kept my cancer private, not an easy choice, not possible for most, but it works for me. We all live and learn, sooner or later the penny will drop and those you're being so patient with will understand and appreciate all you're going through and all those expletives not said... xxx
Posts.Title: Protecting others

Posts.Content: Hi there hun, hang in there, you can do it!  This whole journey is so exhausting, both physically and mentally   Please rest, plan nice things to do between therapies and if you can, throw yourself into something that keeps your mind occupied, a course, reading, films anything... I hope the other ladies will be along with help and support soon, in the meantime I’m sending you the biggest HUG ever xxx
Posts.Title: I am very tired. I have 5 more weekly chemo sessions left.

Posts.Content: Hi there, I fasted for part of my chemo (weekly too), and I believe I had less side effects thanks to this but the main reason I did so is because apparently it can make the chemo more effective too. I fasted 48 hours before and 24 hrs after.  If you can, my only suggestion would be to see a nutritionist that specialises in oncology to guide you through it. I've read a lot about this method by Dr. Longo, I know there are some clinical trials going on that aren't simply to do with fasting but eating a very specific diet. All the best x
Posts.Title: Is anyone trying FASTING (restricting Calories) before chemo to reduce...

Posts.Content: Cathy35 Well done Cathy, keep up the good work! I'm rooting for your 'full and miraculous recovery' Lots of love xxx
Posts.Title: Is anyone trying FASTING (restricting Calories) before chemo to reduce...

Posts.Content: Hi sarah316 I'm a mum of 2 too...Just take one thing at a time, plan 'nice' things to do between the crap ones, let your mind wander and wonder about what's going on but not for too long or you'll get yourself in a tizzy. Post, post, post here as nothing is too big or small and there's always someone around who's been there and thought that... Remember that the treatments are protection and though they aren't easy they are 'doable' (I discovered that word when I was diagnosed and it's helped me through numerous sleepless nights - sod the sheep!) I'm a year on, a very slow, horrible year, but it's passed, time passes, thing get better. I didn't tell anyone except very close family and a couple of friends which worked for me. I cut my hair in the wig shop, so walked in with one style and out with another and have never had any of those looks people give, it would have crushed me, I wouldn't have coped. Now I'm so happy with my decision, I'm sure that was the best choice for me. Remember this is yours, no one can do it for you, make of it what you want. If you don't want the stares or sympathy you don't have to have them, if you want to think about it, no one will blame you if you change your mind when you feel you can cope better with peoples reactions. You need to get to grip with what's going on first and foremost, it's so much, the others can wait. Whatever you decide is the right choice.  All the best xxx
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Hi sarah316 I'm a mum of 2 too...Just take one thing at a time, plan 'nice' things to do between the crap ones, let your mind wander and wonder about what's going on but not for too long or you'll get yourself in a tizzy. Post, post, post here as nothing is too big or small and there's always someone around who's been there and thought that... Remember that the treatments are protection and though they aren't easy they are 'doable' (I discovered that word when I was diagnosed and it's helped me through numerous sleepless nights - sod the sheep!) I'm a year on, a very slow, horrible year, but it's passed, time passes, thing get better. I didn't tell anyone except very close family and a couple of friends which worked for me. I cut my hair in the wig shop, so walked in with one style and out with another and have never had any of those looks people give, it would have crushed me, I wouldn't have coped. Now I'm so happy with my decision, I'm sure that was the best choice for me. Remember this is yours, no one can do it for you, make of it what you want. If you don't want the stares or sympathy you don't have to have them, if you want to think about it, no one will blame you if you change your mind when you feel you can cope better with peoples reactions. You need to get to grip with what's going on first and foremost, it's so much, the others can wait. Whatever you decide is the right choice.  All the best xxx
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Hi Pauletta, I looked for the article you mentioned, but didn't find it. I don't suppose you have link?  I'm fasting a couple of days before and the day of chemo and I find I feel better tummy/mouth wise but obviously it's a very personal decision. I found this article in the Economist, which inspired me to give it a try: www.economist.com/.../starving-the-beast
Posts.Title: tips to reduce side effects before starting chemo, please

Posts.Content: Hi there,  When I got my tattoo, I thought well I've already got a skinhead, all that's missing now is a belly button piercing to be really punk! : )))) I'm in for RT, I'm at n.20 of 25, no side effects (my boob is a bit browner than the other one though). The cream is working, although I go with a completely cream free, clean boob to the RT sessions. September was very quiet, which is good. Good Luck to one and all xxx
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: I am glad you are feeling happier and being pro active! I hope you find a way of getting a second opinion and / or confirmation of your treatment, maybe in a different hospital. I don’t know if that service is available in your area, maybe someone else knows. Second opinions are perfectly legitimate as far as I’m concerned, I had 2 concerning my treatment plan and made it so much easier for me to accept everything.  It’s so great that you are taking control, your post is wonderful! xxx
Posts.Title: Still worried !

Posts.Content: Hi there Julesy1! I finished RT at the beginning of the month. I went with completely clean skin, didn't use any creams etc before radiotherapy, there was a big poster in the waiting room advising against it! (Something to do with how the rays behave once they hit the skin...) I forgot one morning and dashed into the ladies loo, washed my breast and had to dry it with those awful scrapy paper towels....so I recommend a small towel in the handbag for the duration of! I only had one day when my breast was really, really red and it was the day after my Herceptin jab, so I put it down to that drug or to a reaction to the cortisone or some such thing. I also had/have some strange pains but the doctor said it was 'normal' as the breast has been bombarded and I will see how it goes as I have a RT check up in a month. Anyway, I didn't have any problems and now the redness has disappeared too. Good Luck with the therapy!
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: I don't know what you should do but I'm sending you a big HUUUUUUUUUGGGGGGGGG! P.S. I wouldn't give a a toffee if the oncologists get offended, they have a job to do that is 360°, so includes explanations and reassurance...put no.1 first, then smile and wave, girl, smile and wave...another hug! xxx
Posts.Title: Still worried !

Posts.Content: Mrs50 Well done for finishing Chemotherapy, ding ding! I had the same problem, I used eye drops, it helped. I still use them and I'm 6 months on, the watery eyes have improved a lot. I still have a runny nose though... : /
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi there Miss Wolfie I had the same treatment, EC was 3 weekly then Paclitaxel and Herceptin every week for 12 weeks. I fasted for some of my therapy, wish I'd started sooner as I felt better for it, I found the SE's weren't as bad. Take a look at my profile and message me if you want. You'll make it by finding all the strength you never knew you had!!! All the best x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: I have no medical training but this is my tuppence worth! And remember every treatment is different, and everyone is different, and I mean   e v e r y o n e! I think that you will be told the following, take a list of questions and note down the answers as and when and if you don't get the answer to something ask! And if you forget, don't worry, you'll have other occasions and the ladies here will be available! The terms I have put in ' ' are the questions you MIGHT want to ask depending on what the doctors tell you. A good idea is to take your phone and charger and tape the conversation so you can listen to it later calmly, I know my brain switches off after it's heard 2 or 3 new terms and I get in a right old panic trying to keep up! So, If the cancer is 'localised' (not invasive) and has a low 'grade' (like 1 or 2) and small (like yours) normally it's taken out and you only have 'radiotherapy'. Which I hope will be your case, fingers crossed! AND, you can stop reading HERE, you'll never need to know the rest! : ) If not, and forewarned is forearmed and all that, here goes: The bigger the tumour size, the more likely it has spread so the fact it's small means it hasn't been there as long, (mine was 2.2cm) which is good news for you too! Mine was 'Stage' 1 The post surgery 'biopsy' will tell you how aggressive the cancer is, 1, 2 or 3 mine was 'Grade' 3+ so one of the most aggressive forms If it's 'invasive ductal carcinoma' basically this means: invasive = chemotherapy, because the cancer cells aren't confined to the tumour, they have moved into the surrounding tissue. So the chemotherapy is given to protect you. They take out sentinel lymph nodes when you have the op, to check if the cancer has spread, as it's the first place it goes. The lymph nodes are under your arm and so you'll come out of surgery with 2 scars, not one, and a sore shoulder because of the position you are in during surgery. The surgeon told me almost straight away that he thought they looked clear and he was right which was a relief. If your cancer is 'ER positive' it means its hormone sensitive, which is a good thing, because you can be treated with a drug called 'Herceptin' which is a biological therapy and is very effective BUT you have to have your heart monitored continually. My K1 (I saw someone else mentioned it) was K1 67 = 45% , which means the cancer was fast growing but 45% is not very, very fast, it needs to up over 70% for that which is way toooo much information, so I'm going into overload territory! My treatment is Chemotherapy (4 Adriamycin, the nasty one that makes your hair fall out) every 21 days, followed by weekly Herceptin and Paclitaxel (12 sessions - but my hair has already started to regrow - hurrah) I'll then have Radiotherapy 25-30 daily sessions.  Herceptin every 21 days for 14 times (about a years worth) 5 years (at least) of Hormone therapy I'm also having injections even month to get me into menopause but I think that's also age related (I'm 50) And whatever the doctors tell you, it's all doable!  I hope I haven't overloaded you with too much info! I hadn't yet found this forum back in November when diagnosed and I wish I had as I'm the type of person who wants to know everything so I can feel more in control (  of the uncontrollable : )))  ) You mention you feel well and look normal, which is great, who knows, hopefully it will continue like that! Now my cancer has been taken out, as far as I'm concerned I'm completely healthy. I have the Chemotherapy that will protect me, drugs to combat the side effects, a wig and make up to make me look well for me and my family and the outside world. The only thing that I can't control 100% is what's going on in my head, and thats why I'm on this Forum, to share (which is therapeutic) but also to read all the wonderful posts full of advice and love! Good luck
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: What great advice! Ruby Rose really does sum it up. I was operated back in december, 2.2cm, no lymph node involvement but having chemio, radio etc, etc. I found that I despaired and cried and felt traumatised and thought terrible thoughts, but looking back I think well, if I'd known how these things go I would have said, OK - let it on! Time is going to slow down for a bit, because your'e suffering, but once you start focusing on the other aspects of your life again (and you will, it's natural) it'll get it's old pace and flavour back and things will look sunnier.  And you'll get through it, you'll wake up one morning and you'll be calm and accepting and you'll put your fighting face on and it will fit like a glove... God luck and lots of love!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: I think what goes on in our heads is the same for all of us, whatever our diagnosis, as Leolady has said in the past, we're all on the same train.  I haven't made my cancer public, I know that's not easy for some and impossible for others but I managed to tell just a few (positive) close friends and family and have to date never regretted that choice. I realise I've deprived myself of support and who knows what else but I think the peace I have and the time I've given myself to come to terms with what's happened is priceless. As is this community and all of you, priceless x
Posts.Title: "At Least"

Posts.Content: Hi there,  I have a similar problem, veins like wire, pain etc. I massage the area with a cream that’s for varicose veins, it’s improved a teeny tiny bit, maybe give it a try? I hope you find a solution here for us all!
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady56 and Aliblue,  Thanks! Yes, it’s a ‘how long is a piece of strung’ type of question but I have a Birthday a couple of days after the end of my chemo and an event to attend a couple of weeks later and I suppose I’m just trying to prepare ‘excuses’ to not attend if I’m feeling too self conscious about my appearance. Mine have always been really thick so I feel really odd without them in prime condition! Who knows, might never happen, maybe the castor oil will work!  Have a good day ladies! x
Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Morning ladies, I'll be joining you all in a month or so as I'll be finishing chemo soon. I thought this was the best place to ask, I've been told my eyebrows will fall out at the end of chemo, but I'd like to know when, after a week, a month? And how long do they take to grow back, I was told 10 days but that seemed too good to be true. Thanks and I hope thing are going well for you all!
Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Violetsniff I agree that stress could be a factor, it's something I've thought about a lot because I don't have any other 'risk' factors, except dense breasts (and poor sleep left over from when the kids were small). I think strong emotional stress caused or contributed to my getting BC - unfortunately I had a couple of traumatic experiences early last year and was diagnosed in November. I can't help connecting these events, maybe it's just a coincidence, but it keeps niggling at me...and reading you think the same it seems to click Oddly enough, when I went for my RT appointment, the doctor went through a questionnaire which asked about health and lifestyle smoking, drinking etc and sleeping habits, next time I go I'll have to ask why...so sleep must be a contributing factor  I'm curious to know if stress or bad sleep habits have as much 'weight' as smoking or drinking in all this malarky...
Posts.Title: Amount of people with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi there Pollydog, It's a hard decision and to be honest I don't know what I would do if I were in your shoes today.  All I can say is now I'm through the other side I don't regret for a moment having had Chemotherapy. I was completely freaked out, terrified to be honest - but a couple of close friends who have had cancer, (one is a doctor, another a nurse) both repeated to me that I should consider it as 'protection' which seemed weird then because I'd never have thought of it like that, then a friend arrived for a visit and said the same thing - the word 'protection' became my mantra and it's the word I used to explain what was happening to me to my kids too. All the very best to you whatever you decide xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Prevention is the word that really gets me. You can raise awareness of cancer, you can offer screening and suggest healthy lifestyles but 'prevention + cancer' together in any way, means or form make me see red... :  /
Posts.Title: The phrase " kicked cancers Ass"

Posts.Content: This looks really interesting! www.theguardian.com/.../new-breast-cancer-treatment-offers-longer-life-to-younger-women-ribociclib
Posts.Title: Hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer and Riboci...

Posts.Content: I found this thread and I found this article, my trainers are trying to tell me something... www.independent.co.uk/.../exercise-cancer-activity-recovery-physiotherapist-chemotherapy-prescription-a8339876.html
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: A fund raising walk for Breast Cancer research - 'Race for the Cure' - there were 70,000 subscriptions!  It was amazing, we all let off balloons at the end, the big one at the top is mine : )
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi there, I was a swimmer (competition/open water) but haven't been back to the pool since my operation, I found my scars stung with soap so I dread to think what the chlorine would have done to them. Then I had a PIC line put in (a godsend) but it knocked the idea of swimming on the head! (I agree with Denisa on the potential low immunity problems too.)  I started climbing the walls too so I can imagine how you feel.  On the up side I took up Pilates which I love, and it's more sociable which was good for me at that point in my therapy. Oh, and I skiied during chemo too, (I've skied for 30 years but for the first time I was terrified of breaking a bone and interrupting the therapy : O) It was fantastic and I felt amazing! A friend of mine ran all through her chemo so I imagine it really does depend on how you feel. I'm sure the benefits of keeping active are enormous, just listen to your body and don't overdo it and take care of yourself. All the best and hope you keep muddy!!! Hope everyone is doing fine x P.S. Just wondering, if it's dry weather do they make the mud??? : )))
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I walked yesterday and thought of all you lovely ladies somewhere walking with me, while humming 'Walking Back to Happiness'...  : ) xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Get well soon Leolady x I finished radiotherapy Saturday and now have noooooooo excuses, 8.700 steps today. Love and happy walking to all xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Roundhouse1, I had 4 EC, 12 weekly Herceptin + Paclitaxel (then 25 radiotherapy) and am now having Herceptin injections every 3 weeks until next summer. The 12 Herceptin & Paclitaxel made the tip of my tongue tingle/sore, I got cramps in my feet and one arm/hand (the chemo side) and tummy upset. Sometimes my bones ached, from my jaw down to my toes. It's all stuff that I could handle, it never got on top of me too much! I had low white blood count too but the injections and drinking/eating bone broth helped with that as I didn't want to miss therapy, as you can imagine I was impatient to finish it all as it does seem never ending, but the good thing about weekly therapy is that the time flies... I found filling my time with 'nice' things to look forward to helped to keep anxiety at bay, a pretty walk, a relaxing bath, a trip shopping, weekly lunch with a friend (!!! oh thank the lord for those friends who don't mope or pussey foot around but get you up and out - hoorah!!!) Good luck for your mums therapy, take care of her and yourself. All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Weekly Paclitaxel (12 weeks) & herceptin

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose Bleeding heck Ruby Rose, that's drastic, how disappointing not to finish, but more importantly I hope you get the feeling back in your feet soon. I'm sure if the therapy has been suspended it's because it's necessary and possible in your situation.. Looking at it positively, it's only ONE missed therapy and if you see it from a different point of view maybe your body hasn't let you down at all, we are all different, maybe that was all you can take and more importantly all that you need.  Don't wait for the weekend, get the prosecco out!!! Big Hug xxx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: ali owl Sorry to hear your news, I am doing a similar therapy, 4 EC every 3 weeks then 12 weekly Herceptinn & Paclitaxel, then I'll also be having 15 Herceptin jabs that will take me through to July next year. I'm at no.7 of the weekly therapy, I have a few side effects and problems with my bloods but it's much better than EC. The pic line is a godsend and remember you'll get through it! I was soooo worried but once you start the weekly ones it all speeds up. My eyelashes are already growing and so is my hair which is something positive! All the best x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hello there, Frankie Ducky  Good luck with starting chemo, hope it goes smoothly. Mandy 1001 My oncologist staggered my chemotherapy so I could go on a trip to Prague, we had booked it last year and I didn't want to cancel and she didn't bat an eye. I am on weekly chemo so I usually go Monday's, but she had me go Wednesday, then the week away, then Monday again. It was weird, I have always loved travelling but the first 24hrs were a bit tough because I felt I was out of my comfort zone, far from home, hospital etc - completely alien feelings for me that I got over pretty quickly, I'm glad to say. I hope you get to go on your cruise, it'll do you the world of good! Today I had n.11, 5 to go...going to get my red big pen and calendar out now xxx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I had my first post radio check up today, (it's been about 6 weeks since I finished). I told the doctor that I had had a 1 year mammography and she said it shouldn't be done until 6 months post radio because the area remains inflamed and sensitive. Does anyone else have information about mammogram timings, is it 1 year post op or 6 months post radio? I'm concerned it's done more harm than good...
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: Hi Betty Mango, Hair wise it might be better to leave it be, Ihad a sore scalp until my hair fell out, it was really uncomfortable. The only problem cutting your hair shorter (I shaved mine) is that it might make those tiny hairs that are left feel like pins, that’s what happened to me and I couldn’t sleep at night for the discomfort.  I’m having similar problems with wbc, fortunately my oncologist has (finally) prescribed weekly jabs of Filgastrim which should mean no more missed therapies! Fingers crossed Maybe you could ask about the possibility of doing the same depending on how many therapies you have to have? I’m getting impatient, it’s been 6 months and I still haven’t finished! I just want to get the therapies finished now, no more hanging about, I’ve got the rest of my life to get on with... : ) All the best for your therapies ladies, long live the PIC line, mines been a godsend, I hope yours is Ok now Frances Duckie!! x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Looking through your posts, glad to see your fun and grit, it's so hot, maybe the period jabs are playing up with my hormones, Monday n.14, everything aches (I think it's the wbc jabs) it's the 6th month of therapy and I just want to get it finished!!!!!!! Arrrggghhhhh!!!!! P.S. Will now double check the medication for moaning SE's, just to make sure I've covered all the topics P.P.S. So glad you ladies are out there!
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi there chemio ladies, Yesterday I found out I have have low white bloods, again, I've had to miss a couple of therapies and am having injections almost every week now. Worried I might have to miss more at this rate, I should have finished mid July, I'm already nearly a month past that now,...hmmm : ( I had bone broth for lunch, anyone have any (better) suggestions please? x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose Good for you! Final chemo...hurrahhh! I'm on n.14 of 16 and am feeling very, very tired, I think the therapy accumulates and the heat doesn't help either. My oncologist reduced my Paclitaxel because of SE's last week, isn't that weird, a reduced dose has made me almost lethargic too!? Ditto on eyesight too, I'm using eyedrops that improve the situation Roll on tomorrow Ruby Rose x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi there lesleyhelen, Just wanted to say the breast 'dent' can get better if you massage the area, use any cream you prefer. I'm using almond oil at the moment but anyway it gets the breast shape back and avoids any thick tissue forming permanently that can come up on exams and scans and look worrying.  A top notch private surgeon recommended this tip to me as I had a big dent and even though I was months post op when I started massaging it really has made a difference. All the best xxx
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: Dizzy, That's so funny, we travel a lot with the kids and my paediatrician's advice for tummy troubles is also coca cola : ) Bettymango I think the new dog is a wonderful idea, it was the first thing I wanted when I was diagnosed but it got the thumbs down from hubby... BTW I have wbc problems too, I'm experimenting bone broth along with the injections, they shot up from 1000 to 9000 2 weeks ago, this week they went up from 3000 to 6000. Just the jabs don't raise the values as much or sometimes not enough, which means more jabs and more pain (I have pain in my sides/ribs) if you're interested I'll keep you posted on progress x My tum is doing cartwheels so I ate rice pudding for dinner, it's the first thing I've eaten all week that tastes like its supposed to x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi youngatheart I finished over a month ago, my boob was dark and my nipple very brown, now they are nearly the same colour as my non zapped boob and as an added extra post radiotherapy my scar has almost disappeared! Didn't have any rash/spots, maybe you should ask your team about that? xxx
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: MamaSm, so sad to read your news, this is for you and all of us...wishing you all the best xxx
Posts.Title: Cancer’s back

Posts.Content: Just thought I'd share this because BC is traumatic but thankfully this community is full of support: www.bbc.com/.../true-cancer-bodies-adverts-don-t-show-how-traumatic-cancer-is
Posts.Title: BC on BBC

Posts.Content: Hi there, I know this isn't answering your specific question but when I had radiotherapy I put cream on after the therapy but made sure my skin was washed and cream free before to avoid any problems. There was a poster in the waiting room saying to do this. I would ask the doctor in your radiotherapy unit asap. Hope you get it sorted x
Posts.Title: Washing skin during radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi there beacon73, Sorry to hear you’re worried that your therapy isn’t going as you expected Although I was in a very different situation,  I had my chemotherapy interrupted because I had Shingles and was really stressed out. I ended up thinking that the little chemo army was going to be in my system and doing its job for a good while so that thought calmed me down considerably!   High temperature, infections and low white blood count are all common reasons for taking a chemo break. Lots of ladies have chemo-surgery-chemo and if I’ve understood correctly it’s one of the best types of therapy   I had the BRCA test too but after surgery while having chemotherapy. I hope some lovely ladies and gents will be along soon with their words of wisdom.... in the meantime a really massive virtual hug to you... All the best x
Posts.Title: Enforced break in chemo worry

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah,  I’ve been reading through the posts and I think maybe your doctor is talking about 2 things, one is the calcification (2mm) and the other is the lump around it (2cm). That’s how it was explained to me when I was diagnosed. It’s a lot to get your head round at the moment and you’ll exhaust yourself so please try and take a step back, a deep breath, remember you have as much reason to think this will be the best case scenario as the worst! We are all living proof that this is all stuff that can be handled. And whatever is thrown at you there’s something to throw back at it! Loads of stuff in fact It might be an idea to tape your conversation with the doctor/s on your phone so you can listen to it later or make notes of q’s and a’s -, my head was a fuzz during the first appointments, but my husband is a robot from that point of view and could repeat it all back to me word for word  : o  scary but true   I hope your feeling better and that these messages are  of help...big hug x
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy results - breast cancer

Posts.Content: HI Titiushki, I'm an expat too, so I bought a really beautiful wig online at  Lanza Parrucche, it's a German and Italian website and the Raqual Welch/Ellen Willie ones are amazing quality, especially the lace front/monofilament ones. The prices are very low too. Below is the link, it'll give you an idea of styles and prices. If you decide to order online I suggest you get something longer than you see in the pic, they are made for very petite heads and you can always get it cut to suit you x www.parrucchelanza.com/.../home.htm  NatK1 You look great, like you I found shaving my head empowering too, as I could finally control something in all this chaos! What you said to your kids was perfect, wish I'd have thought of that too. I just told mine that I didn't have cancer anymore because it had been removed and now had to take medication to protect me from it coming back, which they were fine with. My kids haven't seen me without a wig or hat though, they don't want to so I try and look like my usual self for me and them x
Posts.Title: Wig purchase advice

Posts.Content: Lots of love to you Leolady56, you're really special! xxx
Posts.Title: Shout out to lovely Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi there Minty63, I'm glad you found this site, it's going to be your best friend for a while. Your therapy sounds familiar in that lots of ladies here have had similar. I threw everything at mine, (see below), I was terrified and had to have a couple of people change my mindset from 'it's gonna be bad' to 'it's gonna protect me', which I repeated like a mantra. The PICC line was fantastic, didn't have any trouble with it. I used it for bloods too, it's a real must. I had 16 chemotherapies, some have 3, everyone is different. Take it a step at a time. I finished chemo in August and radio in October, it was all really tiring. The side effects are manageable with drugs.You'll get through it, we alI got through it...good luck and keep posting - no one will understand like the ladies on here.   Grade 3+ invasive ductal. Her2 Positive. I had 4 EC + 12 x weekly Herceptin and Paclitaxel (02/18 to 08/18) / 25 Radiotherapy (finished 10/18) / 15 Herceptin injections (until summer 2019) / 5 years of Decapeptyl/5 years of Letrozole hormone tablets
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosis and terrified of chemotherapy and radiotherapy...

Posts.Content: Hi RoseKen1, Aspen, I'm on n.10 of 15 Herceptin and it's fine, I only have a runny nose and was very reassured reading Aspen's post as I agree with everything else she says! Thanks x All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hello there positivedad, You've come to the right place, someone is always around with advice and support.  Best Wishes to you and your wife, I hope this treatment isn't too hard on either of you xxx This is the May Chemotherapy Chat link: https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/breast-cancer-forum/180460/may-2019-breast-cancer-chemotherapy-chat This is a link to helpful information that might be useful during therapy: https://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/weblog18/posts/chemo-aids-shopping-list-gathered-from-breast-group-memebrs
Posts.Title: wife about to commence chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Needaname I hope you get the vaccination sorted as it's a real pain having to interrupt Chemio for any reason and to be honest Shingles plus the medication they give means that I feel as bad as I did with the worst weeks of Chemio Chemio last Monday was skipped and I'll be missing next weeks too, I am concerned, the worry switch is firmly ON! Isn't life strange, never thought I'd be upset about not being able to have Chemio...on the upside with all these weeks between therapies my hair might start growing back in the meantime : ) Shingles season...woo hoo! I hope life is being kind to you today...
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi there couttleberry, so sorry you're starting chemo but you're in the best place, this community is great. My hair didn't start falling out until after my second chemotherapy, then I had my head shaved (zero, big mistake) but left longer sideburns because I went the wig/hat route and it made my hairline look more natural. Leave a bit of length to your hair so it lies flat on your head, otherwise when chemo sets in it feels very painful and prickly especially when you go to sleep. Good luck with your therapy xxx
Posts.Title: Hair cut due, what to do?

Posts.Content: Hi peeps, Anyone had shingles during Chemo? I sort of hope not but just in case any advice warmly welcome...thanks!
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Purplepants Sorry I didn’t want to make you feel sad, just wanted to make you feel cared for, because that’s what we all do best in times of need....another HUG Devon Dumpling Wow, 4 surgeries, you’ve got through that, and you’ll get through the next therapies, whatever you choose to do. Sorry to hear your chemo news, doctors tend to give news in dribs and drabs, it happened to me too and looking back on it it meant I had a lovely Christmas as the chemo news came in January as I thought I’d only need radio but no, the whole kaboodle. The only thing that kept me going were 2 friends who both had cancer in their lives, one told me to do everything, to not leave anything to chance as this is too big. The other told me ‘What you’ve got to remember is that chemo is protection, it’s protecring you and keeping you well...’. I admit it was hard to accept but I finished active therapies a month ago and  I’m devastated I had cancer but so grateful we have all this medication and therapies that give us a massive chance of a full recovery. Eyebrows? Mine fell out at the end of chemo, in the meantime I used a pencil to fill in the gaps and they weren’t too bad. On the up side they grew back within 2 months. I think microblading is a good idea before therapy starts as chemo make your skin very sensitive, I think Leolady56 had hers done, maybe she can advise? If you don’t cold cap, hair wise all I can say is I’ve had so many compliments for my hair since I stated wearing a wig, I’m now in a tizz because I’ll have to take it off sooner or later and go back to ‘normal’ hair!! Things we never thought we’d be happy/worried about...go figure?! : ) There is a Chemo thread, lots of lovely ladies, support and advice there  All the best and good luck xxx
Posts.Title: So anxious....

Posts.Content: Hi there Purplepants, I agree with what the ladies above have said, especially the advice about the PICC, get one asap if you can. My right arm still gives me trouble as I had my line put in after I'd d started. Good luck, your fairy god mother will be waiting for you Thursday, she appears in all shapes and sizes, sometimes disguised as a another patient, or a nurse or a lovely lady in the waiting room...I find them all over the place and sometimes I turn into one  ; )  It'll be fine, you've got this and most importantly it's gonna work it's magic by zapping any cancer cells and that means it's protecting the rest of beautiful you MEGAHUGGGGG! xxx
Posts.Title: So anxious....

Posts.Content: Shingles anyone? I was supposed to have my 2nd weekly Paclitaxel/Herceptin today, had filled my week with things to do to keep my mind off it etc, etc but got sent to the 'Infectious Diseases' ward by my oncologist to see a very kind doctor who pronounced what I believed to be a Chemo reaction rash on my upper belly as Shingles!!! So my Chemo is officially suspended (temporarily) and I am on a whole new set of drugs and creams for the foreseeable future! Help! Has anyone had this happen? Any advice warmly welcome... : ( x Make-up really is the answer...and wigs, especially lace front ones....
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hello there, Wink I know what you mean about not having control, it's something I had real trouble dealing with. So, I've become pro-active, doing lots of things to fill my week so it doesn't become all about the chemotherapy - groups, coffee, seeing friends - things to look forward to and that help put the chemotherapy into the back ground. I'm a real worrier, a wonderful doctor gave me some great advice, 'turn off the radar'. The chemotherapy, although harsh and psychologically really devastating is protecting us! Thank heavens it's available... I keep telling myself I'm not ill, because I'm not. The cancer has been removed. The Chemio is gonna kill any of those pesky little cancer cells that are trying to start a rave party in my left big toe and our future is going to be bright..just believe it Remember that you do have control, you just need to tap in to it! Sorry, I don't mean to sound preachy or inspirational but I've struggled so much with all of this 8and still am) that I hope something I've said sticks and helps you too...I repeat all of the above to myself a lot!  - Good news for me is I've started Chemio again after having to suspend my weekly sessions because of Shingles! Hurrah, I'm so relieved! Yesterday 3 nurses spent an hour trying to get a vein in the arm of the lady next to me so anyone having doubts about to PICC or not to PICC - PICC! Have a peaceful week ladies x Love, love, love, la di da...
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi DL, I had the same problem after 4 sessions so had a PICC line put in last Friday (12 to go), it's a doddle, doesn't hurt and I don't even know I have it in most of the time! Don't wait, go for it...it only takes one cack handed nurse to ruin your arm for months, don't take the risk!   If it's too 'late' as you only have a few sessions left, I hope you get a gentle nurse...  : ) Sugartc I found anything with ginger (preferably pure ginger, cold ginger and lemon drinks, cold tea and ginger etc) help with nausea, as does water with lemon juice in it for that funny slimy mouth. Maybe look into taking the drug ondrasetron / Zofran which are little patches that you melt on your tongue and instantly stop nausea, they really worked for me! As does Metoclopramide... Oh, and fennel, straight from the fridge Let us know how you get on, I'm still struggling... Good luck! maggiemee x make-up is the answer...   4 x 3 weekly adriblastina - 12 x weekly herceptin & paclitaxel
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 Hi Leolady, Thanks for your reply! You are my fab link to the outside world! Yes, you are right, this is the season!!! I do have 2 school age children but they are 11 and 14. The doctor reassured me that it's not contagious, it's something that flares up when your auto immune system is 'compromised' which it is, because of the Chemo/cortisone/cocktail of drugs etc. The only precaution was that I should avoid pregnant women. Never thought I'd be upset because I can't have Chemo!!!!!!!!! Arghhh! Ladies....check out any rash asap because apparently catching it within 72 hours makes a big difference in treatment! I thought it was a Chemo reaction... Hope you all have an 'uneventful' Tuesday...   : )
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 I cut all my (very long, never cut : 0 ) hair off after about 6 weeks of chemo because it meant I was taking control of the situation and psychologically it felt better than waiting for it to fall out Think about leaving sideburns that can be used to fake hair when you wear a hat or blend in with a hairline when wearing a wig - strangely enough mine still haven't fallen out...you can always cut them off later if they're not for you. Also, leave an inch or so of hair, I made the mistake of getting it shaved and the stubble was really painful when my hair was falling out, especially when lying down in bed...just some advice to avoid restless nights! Don't forget wigs can be cut and adjusted to your preferred style too, just in case you don't get it right first go! Good luck with the new look, my wig has saved my sanity! xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 Hey there, I'm glad and sad at the same time! I hope the SE of n.3 have worn off and then the rest of your journey goes smoothly! Remember to check in, I love reading your posts! x
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I hope you don't mind me saying, but if I were you I'd ring your doctor back and suggest a Breast Clinic appointment first! Don't take this wrong, not because I think it's something sinister, but because I'd be worrying myself stupid in the meantime!!!  Only saying... : ) All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Can I ask you opinions?

Posts.Content: MaSsIvE hug to you Horsing Around So sorry you got this news, but I agree with Karen.  Everything is protection, take one thing at a time and give yourself time to metabolise what's going on, it's normal to feel shocked, sometimes my head still spins thinking about everything. Breathe, surround yourself with loving, positive people, things will settle down and you'll find a new 'normal' All the best and keep posting, we know where you're at and we need you too...xxx
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Great, let us know how you get on! xxx
Posts.Title: Can I ask you opinions?

Posts.Content: Hi there, So sorry you're here, I hope this might help but please feel free to ask specific questions as and when...and please take what I say with a pinch of salt, everyone is different and some ladies get few to no problems and you might be one of the lucky ones! I had 4 EC and am now at 5th of 12 Paclitaxel/Hercptin and although the medicines aren't exactly the same, the psychological stress is... Get the PORT or PICC, I had the EC without and regret it, my veins have turned to wire and hurt, I had the PICC put in before the cycle of 12. You will probably feel Ok the first couple of sessions, but keep taking the medication to keep the SE's at bay, don't suffer unnecessarily. I found the 4th the worst. You'll probably get upset stomach, nausea, I take probiotics to help with that, plus cold ginger drinks, lemon etc were a godsend for nausea. Fresh air and keeping active is also a great help. I shaved my (  v.long : (  ) hair off, because I wanted to take control of something and I couldn't bear the idea of it falling out (no cold cap option here, otherwise I would have tried it). If you decide to cut, leave an inch or so because your scalp gets painful and shaved hair is prickly and painful, it'll keep you awake at night. After the 4 EC I was a psychological wreck with the prospect of 12 more sessions. That's when I found this community (hurrah!) The good thing is once they start they are weekly so getting bloods done and PICC cleaned and then therapy doesn't leave much time to worry about the next one because it's on you before you know it. The 2 drugs take between 3 and 4 hours to administer and the side effects are less expected. I have the usual stomach upset, metal mouth but also a reduction of my vision and aches and pains, leg/foot pain etc but it's usually episodes that don't last very long and so far completely bearable, I don't need medication for it. The psychological part is harder, I often meet a friend for lunch, go to a bookclub, for walks, I took up courses, pottery, pilates, stuff that was new and challenging and kept my mind off all this malarky and gave me stuff to look forward to (not just to dread) and help/ed fill my head with 'nice' thoughts. I have kids too but I think cutting out some time for me really makes a difference, so if you can, be a bit selfish, I know my kids were surprised but not upset, I switched up the love, caring, hugs, button for them and my husband and it seems to have worked because if I'm Ok, they are Ok...we all know that's the first rule of mumming : ) The actual sessions are fine, you get other drugs before the Chemo that make me a bit woozy. The PICC has been a godsend, I go alone and have always has the most lovely chemo companions that make the time fly with their chat... You will be fine, it's something we can and will do, and we will come out the other side stronger and wiser, and on those bad days we'll be here for you. All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo Jitters

Posts.Content: Why me? Try me!
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi there, I'm using a gentamicin sulfate cream (I don't live in the UK so can't help with the brand name, sorry) on my toenails, they looked as though I was going to lose them but have really improved since I started using the cream. I hope you find something similar, all the best xxx
Posts.Title: Hand nails turning black from chemotherapy. Any advice please?

Posts.Content: Me! Mine were low before diagnosis, ( I found out doing routine bloods because of Thyroid problems) I was taking supplements when I was diagnosed with bc (about a year or so before) and still am as my oncologist regularly puts it into the list of blood tests I have to do so it must be important... My endrocrinologist agrees with these supplements and doses too...so I'm happy and confident it's important I take a liquid supplement every 2 weeks I live in sunnier climes but unfortunately I am not a sun worshipper! : ))))   House swap anyone???  : ))))))))))))
Posts.Title: vitamin D - who knows their vitamin D levels are low ?

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28 I had a DEXA scan a few weeks ago, I have the beginning of Osteoporosis, the rheumatologist has booked me in for 6 monthly injections for the next 5 (or 10) years that I'll be taking Letrozole and having Decapeptyl injections. She said it will help combat the side effects of the hormone therapies... the joys! My Thyroid and vitamin D issues were pre bc diagnosis but I suppose there's no way of knowing if they were pre cancer?! The information I've read thus far indicate cause, not effect but I'm interested to see what you find out. Good Luck with your research, keep us updated. xxx
Posts.Title: vitamin D - who knows their vitamin D levels are low ?

Posts.Content: It tried to bury me in the ground but it didn't realize I was a seed...
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi there, I was told by a surgeon that over 70% was considered a 'fast growing' Ki. Mine was 45% Good luck with your therapy xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone know about ki67 test?

Posts.Content: Hi there WhatHappened, Your post got me thinking, I saw my oncologist today and asked what exactly causes the pain, if it's the lowering of oestrogen levels or something in the pill that triggers it.... she said both! I really wasn't expecting that reply.... Still, moving does help generally but I walked quite a bit this weekend (did a few miles on a pebbly beach) and was in pain and felt like I was 101! Still, it's always good to be out and feeling 'normal', ha, ha!  Thanks for your input, always good to get other peoples angle on things! xxx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: Hi there, No I'm still hesitating! : )  And wondering about side effects... : 0 My oncologist upped my dose of vitamin D and gave me a supplement with magnesium so I'm going to see how they work out before changing. I'm only on my 3rd pack of Letrozole, I was fine bone wise up until I finished radiotherapy. I'm lactose intolerant so the original problem was tummy troubles. So basically now I am trying to stick with it a bit longer to see if things improve bone wise and am going to see a nutritionist to find out what havoc it's reaping on my intestine! Fingers crossed from dithering me x
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: Hi there Ginacarla I asked the same question on the Letrozole side effects thread a while back but haven't had a reply yet so hope to see some responses here... My oncologist has prescribed me Exemestane but as she can't say if I'm going to feel better I'm hesitating, so we are in the same boat!  All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: Hi Kimbeloo, I have been told repeatedly that invasive = chemotherpy My personal view is I'm not a statistic, I'm a person that wants to be 'protected' by all that medical science can throw at me, and I don't want any regrets... (   and you never know if a couple of those pesky little cancer cells have decided to have a rave party somewhere fun in your body, and none of us want that, they might get frisky and start multiplying  ; )   )
Posts.Title: Refusing chemotherapy after Her2+ results

Posts.Content: Hi there, Been reading through the posts, I'm so glad you are all out there sharing your news! I had the first of 12 weekly Herceptin and Paclitaxel on Monday, (via a PICC line). It was fine, they gave the Herceptin first, followed by the Paclitaxel, it took about 3 and a half hours. I've been taking the back up medication (gastro protection, cortisone etc) for 3 days but had tummy troubles yesterday and today, fingers crossed it was just a blip! I'm feeling fine, my energy levels are better than with Adriblastina, have even been able to cook as the nausea has subsided... I also have a little hair growth on my head, fingers crossed! Eyebrows are a no go area though!   : / I was really panicking about having 12 more sessions! I asked my oncologist if I could have only 4 (bigger doses) every 21 days but she explained the results are much better this way - I suppose because the medication works it's way out of your system so having it more often means you are better protected. She also said the side effects are less this way, which also makes sense as the dose is lower. Sooooo, my tactic for getting through the 12 weeks (which was really getting me down psychologically) came naturally as I got an invite to go out Sunday and from then on I have been filling my week with little 'nice' things to do, I went for a lovely long walk, went to the cinema, did pilates, met a friend for coffee...the idea being that my week doesn't revolve around chemio now that its weekly but the chemo fits into all the 'nice' things I do during my week and that way it becomes secondary...I hope that makes sense For the moment it's helping me see the light at the end of the tunnel... I hope all you lovely people are with me visualising the May Chemotherapy zapping those cancer cells away like an 80's computer game! On the subject of supplements, when I asked my oncologist about taking iron tablets with B12 she very diplomatically said she didn't like the B family...so there's my cereal out the window too! maggiemee x make-up is the answer...
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Kimbeloo, I have been told repeatedly that invasive = chemotherpy My personal view is I'm not a statistic, I'm a person that wants to be 'protected' by all that medical science can throw at me, and I don't want any regrets... (   and you never know if a couple of those pesky little cancer cells have decided to have a rave party somewhere fun in your body, and none of us want that, they might get frisky and start multiplying  ; )   )
Posts.Title: Refusing chemotherapy after Her2+ results

Posts.Content: Thanks Leolady56! Hi there, I'm new to the community : / I was operated in December, have already had the 4 'red' chemio every 21 days and start the 12 weekly Pacltaxel/Herceptin and wanted to know what it's like from anyone who's in the throws of, or has finished this cycle of therapy. I had nausea, upset stomach, sore arm and tiredness with the first 4 (red) but I was expecting it to be sooooo much worse so am counting my blessings I didn't wait for my hair to fall out, but cut it all off, and too short to boot (my scalp was tender and the 'stubble' hurt) - I wish I'd left it a bit longer as It hasn't ever fallen out completely which might have given me a head start when it finally starts growing back...or maybe not...hmmm Anyway, the lovely lady who cut my hair left me some 'side burns' which haven't fallen out and are pretty useful when wearing a wig (they help 'blend' into the hairline) or a hat/scarf as it gives you the appearance of having hair underneath - just a bit frightful when your head isn't covered, which in my case is neverrrrr! ; ) Apart from all the other drugs that go with the therapy I'm taking some extra 'natural' stuff, vitamin D, probiotics for my stomach/intestine, organic aloe arborenscens (syrup) to detox and am having Epsom salt baths. So, back to chemio, the idea of having n.12 sessions, every week, starting next week, is really freaking me out, as is the state of my veins after only 4 therapies - I'm going to see about getting a PIC line in, any tips warmly welcome! Pacltaxel / Herceptin - What are the side effects? (I've Googled it but I find Google is bad for my health iykwim) Does this therapy have less side effects than Adriamycin? What are your veins/arm like after 16 therapies? Anyone taking any 'alternative' medication along with the prescribed stuff, if so, what? Has anyones hair grown back during weekly therapy with these drugs? (...she said hopefully...) Sorry, too many questions?! : ) Any advice warmly welcome! Thanks for being there peeps, you really do make a difference... x Life's tough, but so are you x
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thanks, horses held... I've read everything, that's why I'm here in the community, to hear first hand experience of the what, where, do's and don'ts. If everything 'official' I read was true, I didn't have breast cancer, and wouldn't be having chemio now, nothing fits - because everyone is different. Like the most part of those reading this, I don't have any of the list of 'risk factors', nothing...and to top that (just an example), my cancer didn't show up on the mammogram...I saw 5 doctors/specialists before I was diagnosed, again, probably nothing new to you ladies out there... : ( Yes, I totally agree, our imagination can (and will) go into overdrive... I'm not being cynical, I'm way past that, i just want concrete, first hand experience...because forewarned is forearmed ; ) Thanks x x
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady, I read about your ex onco and am soo shocked! The protocols are international and an oncologist who meddles with them is soon wrong...now you are putting things back in order and to will be fine! Oh, really surprised to see your post about Paclitaxel and Perception being delivered separately. I start on them Monday and have been told I will have them both in one sitting...now I'm scratching my head wondering what all these different protocols mean in terms of treatment. A friend of mine explained that Herceptin is biological, it attaches itself to Cancer cells and assassinates them...good huh!  Being HER2 positive is positive then! (excuse the pun : )) (P.S. I had my PIC line put in today, two nurses jollied me along, and it was fine thank goodness! The only surprise was the X-ray afterwards to check the position but hey ho, no more veins to worry about!)
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
